trial_identification.studytitle: Efficacy of the Zap and Run defibrillator skills training program for health care workers.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Efficacy of the Zap and Run defibrillator skills training program for health care workers.

conditions.healthcondition: Defibrillator use by health care workers.

interventions.interventions: The intervention is a fifteen minute one to one training workshop. It uses a simulated defibrillator [ALSi] to practice skills involved in rhythm recognition, defibrillation, cardioversion and pacing. All trainers are experience critical care physicians who record adherence to ALS guidelines using a data sheet and the logging function of the simulator.
interventions.comparator: There is no separate control group. The methodology is within group analysis of measures undertaken during the workshop to determine skill levels and acceptability of the training.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Number of errors in treatment detected by the trainer using a checklist comparing treatment to ALS guidelines while observing the performance of the participant on the ALSi simulator.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Testing occurs during the workshop with coaching after the test is undertaken.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Time to complete critical tasks is measured by the ALSi simulator during the training session.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Testing occurs during the workshop with coaching after the test is undertaken.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Participants will be asked to evaluate the workshop using a five point Likert scale to assess perceived ease and usefulness of training.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Testing occurs during the workshop with coaching after the test is undertaken.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Critical care and anaesthesia medical and nursing staff

trial_design.statisticalmethods: Descriptive statistics of baseline performance and nonparametric comparisons of before after measures. The target of 100 participants was chosen as a sample of convenience to provide information on medical and nursing staff.

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: Department of Anaesthesia, St. George Hospital

fundingsource.fundingname: St George Hospital Department of Anaesthesia

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
Zap and Run is a ten minute one on one training workshop focused on developing and maintaining skills in use of a cardiac defibrillator for rhythm recognition, defibrillation, cardioversion and external pacing. It utilises the portable ALSi simulator. This project aims to evaluate the skills of participants while undertaking the workshop. Participants will be asked to rate their training experience and time to treat will be measured using the logging features of the simulator. This evaluation will be used to determine the skills gap and need for training.
The workshop consists of testing the skills of participants using a simulated defibrillator over seven scenarios. The simulator logs the times and actions of the participant. The instructor then explains and corrects any errors and the scenario is run again if necessary to confirm learning before moving to the next scenario. At the beginning and end of the workshop the participant will fill out a workshop evaluation questionnaire.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: South Eastern Sydney LHD Human Research Ethics Committee
